options: Reduced transmission times
Limited RAM
Reduced amount of processing power
Higher quality files
Which of these is a valid reason for com.feedback: Compression is used to reduce the storage space required by a file, meaning you can store more files with the same amount of storage space. Compression is particularly important for sharing files over networks or the Internet. The larger a file, the longer it takes to transfer and so compressing files increases the number of files that can be transferred in a given time.

options: To generate a similar copy of the original file
When all the information is needed
To fully generate the original file
To download work documents from a website
When is lossy compression used?.feedback: lossy compression reduces the size of a file while also removing some of its information such that there is minimal difference between the old and original. This can be applied to photos, video, or audio files. \n Important files such as word documents require lossless compression where all the original data needs to be recoverable

options: Uses at least one key to cipher data
Is only used on text
Is impossible to break
Makes data less secure
Encryption....feedback: Encryption is used to keep data secure when it is being transmitted. There are a variety of different methods which can be used to scramble data before it is transmitted and then decipher it once it arrives at its destination.

options: Use a single key to encode/decode data
Are the most secure types of encryption
Include multiple keys to encode/decode data
Used by a majority of large digital media distribution companies such as Youtube
Symmetrical encryption techniques....feedback: In symmetric encryption, both the sender and receiver share the same private key, which they distribute to each other in a process called a key exchange. This key is used for both encrypting and decrypting data.  \n \n Itâ€™s important that the private key is kept secret. If the key is intercepted during the key exchange then any communications sent can be intercepted and decrypted using the key. Asymmetric encryption gets around this issue.

options: Use multiple keys to encode/decode data
Use a single key to encode/decode data
Are the least secure type of encryption
More vulnerabilities associated with this encryption method compared to Symmetrical encryption
Is lossy
Is lossless
Records the number of repeats of an individual element
Can be used for a wide variety of file types
Which of these is FALSE about Run-length.feedback:
Run length encoding is a method of lossless compression in which repeated values are removed and replaced with one occurrence of the data followed by the number of times it should be repeated.  
 
 For example, the string BBBBCCCDDDDDD could be represented as B4C3D6 
 
 In order to work well, run length encoding relies on adjacent pieces of data being the same - if there is little repetition, run length encoding doesn't offer a great reduction in file size.

options: A dictionary is sent along with the data during transmission
Creates a dictionary of smaller letters so less space is used
Doesn't send the dictionary with the data
Is a lossy compression format
Which of these is TRUE about dictionary.feedback: Dictionary encoding is another example of lossless compression. Frequently occurring pieces of data are replaced with an index and the compressed data is stored alongside a dictionary which matches the frequently occurring data to an index. The original data can then be restored using the dictionary. \n \n It's important to remember that data compressed using dictionary compression must be transferred alongside its dictionary. Without a dictionary, the data cannot be decompressed.

Which of these is NOT TRUE for a databas.feedback: In first normal form there must be no attribute that contains more than a single value.

What is TRUE for a database in 2NF (Seco.feedback: A database which doesn't have any partial dependencies and is in first normal form can be said to be in second normal form. This means that no attributes can depend on part of a composite key, they have to depend on both.

options: There are no transitive (non-key) relationships
There are at least 4 tables in the database
There is no dependence
All attributes have a separate table
What is TRUE for a database in 3NF (Thir.feedback: If the database is in 2NF and contains no non-key (transitive) dependencies, it is in third normal form. A non-key dependency means the attribute only depends on the value of the primary key and nothing else.

options: connected
virtual
broken
individual
Greater bandwidth can lead to a faster network
Wireless networks tend to be faster than wired
Wired networks are less reliable than wireless
Less bandwidth can lead to a faster network
Which of the following is TRUE of networ.feedback: The network bandwidth is how much data can be transferred over a network in a given time. Thus, the greater the bandwidth, the faster/more data can be sent over a network. The bandwidth is shared between all active users, so performance can decrease if there are too many users. \n \n Wireless networks are also less reliable than wired networks. Wired networks have a direct connection to the router or switch, whereas wireless networks are prone to obstruction such as walls and become slower the further you are from the switch/router.

options: Single point of failure
Server performs can automate tasks so the clients don't have to
Server is responsible for the security of data
Automatic back ups are performed by the server to keep data up to date
What is a disadvantage of a Client-Serve.feedback:
Client-server networks consist of terminals known as clients connected to a server. The server is a powerful, central computer. It holds all of the important information and resources and has greater processing power than the terminals. 
 
 Advantages: 
 - More secure as data is stored in a central location 
 - Central backups are carried out so there is no need for individual backups 
 
 Disadvantages: 
 - Relatively expensive to set up. 
 - If the server fails, the clients will no longer function coherently 
 - Trained staff are required to maintain the server.

options: Cheap to set up
Impossible to trace the origin of files
Peers individually backup their data
Peers individually secure their data
What is an advantage of a peer-to-peer m.feedback:
A peer-to-peer network is where computers (peers) are connected to each other so that they can share files. Each device effectively acts as both a server and client, as it can both provide and request resources. Each peer is equally as important as every other peer. 
 
 Advantages: 
 - Cheaper to set up 
 - Allows users to share resources 
 - Easy to Maintain and add new peers 
 - Not dependent on central server 
 
 Disadvantages: 
 - Impossible to trace the origin of files (allows for piracy) 
 - Backups must be performed separately 
 - Poorer security 
 - May be difficult to locate resources
